prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISE 1302-2147 OH-18OH velocity profiles at z=2.707
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Range to cover the OH119 and 18OH120 velocity profiles including wings and baseline out to -2600 km/s from the blue component of the OH doublet and +1500 km/s from the red component of the 18OH doublet with continuum signal-to-noise-ratio of 40. Coverage past the 18OH doublet just redward of the OH doublet is necessary in order to provide a good baseline for the derivation of the OH doublet profile.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a signal-to-noise ratio on the continuum of 40 with a velocity bandwidth of 300 km/s in order to enable detection of velocity shifts and broad wings. This was typical of the minimum SNR we required for our Herschel observations of local ULIRGs at similar spectral resolution. For this we conservatively derive the continuum at the observed frequency based on linear interpolation of the Herschel SPIRE 350 and 500 micron fluxes of 39.3 and 49.3 mJy, respectively.
In available 870 micron and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARMA/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA Cycle 0, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6" and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, ie <0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the required sensitivity.
The requested set-up is needed to enable accurate centroiding of the the absorption and emission components.

In available 870 and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARM/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6 arc seconds and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, i.e < 0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the requrired sensitivity.
Note, that if the OT does not take into consideration that Band 9 is DSB in its sensitivity calculation, then a longer time may be needed to achieve the required continuum SNR.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISE 2201+0226 OH-18OH velocity profile at z=2.876
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Range to cover the OH119 and 18OH120 velocity profiles including wings and baseline out to -2600 km/s from the blue component of the OH doublet and +1500 km/s from the red component of the 18OH doublet with continuum signal-to-noise-ratio of 40. Coverage past the 18OH doublet just redward of the OH doublet is necessary in order to provide a good baseline for the derivation of the OH doublet profile.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a signal-to-noise ratio on the continuum of 40 with a velocity bandwidth of 300 km/s in order to enable detection of velocity shifts and broad wings. This was typical of the minimum SNR we required for our Herschel observations of local ULIRGs at similar spectral resolution. For this we conservatively derive the continuum at the observed frequency based on linear interpolation of the Herschel SPIRE 350 and 500 micron fluxes of 134.6 and 82.2 mJy, respectively.
In available 870 micron and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARMA/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA Cycle 0, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6" and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, ie <0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the required sensitivity.
Note, that if the OT does not take into consideration that Band 9 is DSB in its sensitivity calculation, then a longer time may be needed to achieve the required continuum SNR.
The requested set-up is needed to enable accurate centroiding of the the absorption and emission components.

In available 870 and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARM/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6 arc seconds and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, i.e < 0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the requrired sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISE 2300+0212 OH-18OH velocity profiles at z=2.771
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Range to cover the OH119 and 18OH120 velocity profiles including wings and baseline out to -2600 km/s from the blue component of the OH doublet and +1500 km/s from the red component of the 18OH doublet with continuum signal-to-noise-ratio of 40. Coverage past the 18OH doublet just redward of the OH doublet is necessary in order to provide a good baseline for the derivation of the OH doublet profile.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a signal-to-noise ratio on the continuum of 40 with a velocity bandwidth of 300 km/s in order to enable detection of velocity shifts and broad wings. This was typical of the minimum SNR we required for our Herschel observations of local ULIRGs at similar spectral resolution. For this we conservatively derive the continuum at the observed frequency based on linear interpolation of the Herschel SPIRE 350 and 500 micron fluxes of 86.0 and 62.9 mJy, respectively.
In available 870 micron and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARMA/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA Cycle 0, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6" and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, ie <0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the required sensitivity.
We note that for this source the part of the 18OH doublet is affected by a semi-opaque ozone absorption feature that will lower both the signal-to-noise ratio and the accuracy of the line profile if there is imperfect calibration through this feature. Nevertheless we request this additional range covering the expected 18OH doublet and adjacent continuum to provide an accurate continuum level on the low frequency side of the OH doublet.
Also note that if the sensitivity calculation of the OT does not take into consideration that Band 9 is double side band (DSB) thus lowering the sensitivity, then a longer time may be needed to achieve the required continuum SNR.
The requested set-up is needed to enable accurate centroiding of the the absorption and emission components.

In available 870 and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARM/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6 arc seconds and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, i.e < 0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the requrired sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Range to cover the OH119 and 18OH120 velocity profiles including wings and baseline out to -2600 km/s from the blue component of the OH doublet and +1500 km/s from the red component of the 18OH doublet with continuum signal-to-noise-ratio of 40. prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a signal-to-noise ratio on the continuum of 40 with a velocity bandwidth of 300 km/s in order to enable detection of velocity shifts and broad wings. This was typical of the minimum SNR we required for our Herschel observations of local ULIRGs at similar spectral resolution. For this we conservatively derive the continuum at the observed frequency based on linear interpolation of the Herschel SPIRE 350 and 500 micron fluxes of 93.8 and 75.1 mJy, respectively.
In available 870 micron and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARMA/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA Cycle 0, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6" and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, ie <0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the required sensitivity.
We note that for this source part of the 18OH doublet is affected by a semi-opaque ozone absorption feature that will lower both the signal-to-noise ratio and the accuracy of the line profile if there is imperfect calibration through this feature. Nevertheless we request this additional range covering the expected 18OH doublet and adjacent continuum to provide an accurate continuum level on the low frequency side of the OH doublet.
Also note that if the sensitivity calculation of the OT does not take into consideration that Band 9 is double side band (DSB) thus lowering the sensitivity, then a longer time may be needed to achieve the required continuum SNR.
The requested set-up is needed to enable accurate centroiding of the the absorption and emission components.

In available 870 and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARM/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6 arc seconds and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, i.e < 0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the requrired sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WISE 2246-0526 OH84 and 18OH85 velocity profiles at z=4.605
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Range to cover the OH84 and 18OH85 velocity profiles including wings and baseline out to -2600 km/s from the blue component of the OH doublet and +1500 km/s from the red component of the 18OH doublet with continuum signal-to-noise-ratio of 40. Coverage past the 18OH doublet just redward of the OH doublet is necessary in order to provide a good baseline for the derivation of the OH doublet profile.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested set-up is needed to enable accurate centroiding of the the absorption and emission components.

In available 870 and millimeter continuum observations of Hyperluminous Hot DOGs with CARM/SMA, PdBI, and ALMA, they are unresolved at resolutions 0.7, 1.2, and 1.6 arc seconds and could very well be unresolved in our proposed observations with the most compact 12-meter configuration at 450 microns, i.e < 0.5". The observations can also be spatially smoothed to 1" or 2" which will still provide the requrired sensitivity.

We require a signal-to-noise ratio on the continuum of 40 with a velocity bandwidth of 300 km/s in order to enable detection of velocity shifts and broad wings. This was typical of the minimum SNR we required for our Herschel observations of local ULIRGs at similar spectral resolution. For this we conservatively derive the continuum at the observed frequency based on linear interpolation of the Herschel SPIRE 350 and 500 micron fluxes of 81 and 44 mJy, respectively.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In this program we seek to synergize two major discoveries: 1) the Herschel discovery of massive, v~1000 km/s molecular outflows in local ULIRGs, apparently powered by AGN fueled during the galaxy merger and 2) the WISE discovery of a class of rare hyperluminous hot dust-obscured galaxies (Hot DOGs) that may represent a short transitional stage of galaxy merging in which the AGN has partially cleared the mergers star-forming ISM. In local ULIRGs the character of the molecular flows (outflows/inflows) are best traced by FIR transitions of OH, so we propose to observe 5 hyperluminous Hot DOGs at z~2.7-4.6 in the strongest OH doublet at 119.3 microns that in ULIRGs with outflows shows P-Cygni or blue-winged absorption profiles that unambiguously indicate outflowing gas. Detection of outflows would provide support for the posits of both discoveries: that luminous AGN power the molecular outflows in ULIRGs and that the Hot DOGs are powered by AGN during transitional periods of strong feedback. Conversely, detection of inverse P-Cygni profiles would signify inflowing gas, identifying flows that could be responsible for the extreme luminosities of the 1000 most luminous DOGs known.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: There are several proposals submitted in Cycle 3 to observe WISE ELIRGs. PI Assef is probing the high-resolution [CII] emission from the most luminous galaxy W2246 in 2005.1.00309, and continuing a search for [CII] started in Cycle-2 in 2015.1.00612. PI Diaz-Santos is observing the fine-structure line [NII] in W2246-0526, but at lower resolution, in 2005.1.00XXX. These proposals have complementary goals, and do not rely upon each others results to succeed.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00152.S, Hyperluminous Hot DOGs: Hosts to High-Velocity Molecular Outflows? An Early Science Exploration, PI J. Fischer
